Description: Cast (?) bowl: green glass, now translucent, cloudy and iridescent but probably originally transparent. The ribs radiate from the centre of the base and increase in depth as they approach the rim. As usual, the ribs terminate about 1 cm below the rim. Interior wheel-turned. Moulded.
Curator's comments: Pillar-moulded bowls were probably made in various centres throughout the eastern Mediterranean including Egypt. The present specimen was presumably acquired in Egypt and may be of Egyptian origin but it is impossible to be certain. While the date indicated above is probably accurate, an earlier date is also possible. Petrie found fragments of these bowls at San el-Hagar in a context of the second century A.D. (1885,1101.323 and 1885,1101.324). However, in excavating the Kushite royal burials Reisner found fragments apparently dating from the third and second centuries B.C. Bibliography : W. M. F. Petrie 'et al.', 'Tanis' I (1885), 49, lower right; D. Dunham, ‘The Royal Cemeteries of Kush’ IV(Boston 1950-1963), 55 (16-2-356), 93 (16-2-180) and figs. 29 and 61.
